skill.name: remembering-conversations
skill.description: Use when user asks 'how should I...' or 'what's the best approach...' after exploring code, OR when you've tried to solve something and are stuck, OR for unfamiliar workflows, OR when user references past work. Searches conversation history.
skill.summary: Search past Claude Code conversations to avoid repeating work and leverage historical context.
skill.author: obra

security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. MCP tool names in documentation were misidentified as shell commands. Documentation example paths were flagged as hidden file access. Generic pattern matching triggered crypto and reconnaissance warnings on benign text. The skill only dispatches search tasks to a dedicated agent - no direct command execution, no network access, no sensitive operations.

content.value_statement: Claude Code often repeats work or forgets solutions found in past conversations. This skill searches your conversation archive to retrieve past decisions, code patterns, and solutions without consuming your context window.
actual_capabilities: Search past conversations using semantic similarity and text matching
Dispatch to a specialized search agent for efficient retrieval
Read full conversations or specific line ranges from the archive
Filter searches by date range to focus on recent or historical context
Return synthesized insights with source citations
Avoid wasting context window on loading raw conversation history
limitations: Only searches local conversation archives stored in user config directory
Cannot access conversations that were not archived by the episodic-memory plugin
Search agent dispatch adds small latency compared to direct tool use
Very large conversation files may take longer to read and process

use_cases.title: Recover Past Implementation Details
use_cases.description: A developer wants to continue work on a feature they discussed weeks ago. They ask how a particular API was implemented. The skill searches past conversations to find the original implementation and explain the approach that was decided.
use_cases.target_user: Developers working on long-term projects with paused work

use_cases.title: Recall Research Findings
use_cases.description: A researcher is investigating a complex problem and needs to remember what was discovered in earlier sessions. The skill searches the conversation archive to surface relevant investigation threads and their conclusions.
use_cases.target_user: Researchers and problem solvers investigating complex topics

use_cases.title: Maintain Team Context Across Sessions
use_cases.description: A team lead needs to onboard a new developer and wants to share the history of architectural decisions. The skill searches past conversations to compile a timeline of key decisions and their rationales.
use_cases.target_user: Team leads and project managers maintaining continuity

prompt_templates.title: Simple Topic Search
prompt_templates.prompt: Search our conversation history for information about [topic]. What decisions were made and what code patterns were used?
prompt_templates.scenario: Quick lookup of past discussions on a specific topic

prompt_templates.title: Pattern and Approach Search
prompt_templates.prompt: Find conversations about [pattern or approach]. I want to understand how we handled [specific challenge] in the past and what worked or did not work.
prompt_templates.scenario: Learning from historical solutions and mistakes

prompt_templates.title: Date-Restricted Search
prompt_templates.prompt: Search conversations from [start date] to [end date] for discussions about [topic]. Focus on decisions made during that period.
prompt_templates.scenario: Finding context within a specific time window

prompt_templates.title: Deep Investigation Search
prompt_templates.prompt: Search for all conversations about [complex topic] including related concepts like [concept 1], [concept 2], and [concept 3]. Read the top results and synthesize what we discovered, what patterns emerged, and what open questions remain.
prompt_templates.scenario: Comprehensive research across multiple conversation threads

output_examples.input: Search for conversations about React authentication patterns
output_examples.output:
I found 3 relevant conversations:

**Project Alpha** (Oct 2024) - We implemented JWT authentication with refresh tokens. Key decisions: stored tokens in httpOnly cookies, added CSRF protection, used axios interceptors for automatic token refresh.

**API Migration** (Nov 2024) - Switched to Auth0 for external users. Lessons learned: Auth0 SDK simplified token management but required custom claim validation.

**Current Session** (Dec 2024) - No new authentication work detected.

Would you like me to read any of these conversations in full?

output_examples.input: What do we know about the database schema for users?
output_examples.output:
From past conversations, the user schema includes:

- id (UUID primary key)
- email (unique, indexed)
- name
- created_at / updated_at (timestamps)
- role (enum: admin, user, viewer)

Note: A migration was planned to add last_login_at and preferences (JSONB) but may not have been implemented yet. Check the migrations folder for status.

best_practices: Dispatch the search agent first when you need historical context rather than loading raw conversations directly
Use specific search queries with multiple concepts to narrow results to the most relevant conversations
Check the date range when you know approximately when the relevant discussion occurred
Cite sources when presenting information from past conversations so users can verify or read more
anti_patterns: Loading raw conversation files directly without searching first - wastes context window
Searching for information that is clearly available in the current codebase or conversation
Forgetting to check past conversations before making decisions that may have been already discussed
Using overly broad search queries that return too many irrelevant results

faq.question: What conversations does this skill search?
faq.answer: It searches conversations archived by the episodic-memory plugin. Conversations are stored locally in your user configuration directory. Only conversations that were explicitly archived will appear in search results.

faq.question: How does this skill differ from using Grep or Read directly?
faq.answer: The search agent understands semantic meaning, not just text matching. It can find conversations about related concepts even when the exact words differ. It also synthesizes findings rather than returning raw data.

faq.question: Can this skill modify or delete my conversation history?
faq.answer: No. This skill only has read access to search and display past conversations. It cannot delete, edit, or archive conversations. Those operations require separate tools.

faq.question: Is my conversation data sent to external servers?
faq.answer: No. All conversations are stored locally on your machine. The search operation happens against your local database. No data is transmitted externally.

faq.question: How accurate is the semantic search?
faq.answer: The skill uses sqlite-vec with embeddings for semantic similarity and SQLite FTS5 for text matching. Accuracy depends on query specificity and embedding quality. Combining both modes provides the best results.

faq.question: What affects search performance?
faq.answer: Search itself is fast (typically under 100ms). Reading full conversations takes longer for large files. Use startLine and endLine parameters to limit the range when you know approximately where the relevant content is located.
